metadata.title: Title: A facile method of mapping neutralizing HIV-1 epitopes

abstract.text: Identification of specific epitopes targeted by neutralizing antibodies is essential to advance 14 epitope-based vaccine design strategies. We report a methodology for rapid epitope mapping 15 of neutralizing antibodies against HIV-1 Env at single residue resolution, using viral 16 neutralization assays and deep sequencing. We extended our methodology to map multiple 17 specificities of epitopes targeted in polyclonal sera, elicited in immunized animals as well as 18 in HIV-1 infected patients.

body_text.text: Main 34 We recently described a methodology to decipher epitopes of monoclonal antibody panels 35 using yeast surface display, Cys labeling and deep sequencing 1, 2 . Here we built on this to map 36 epitopes of neutralizing monoclonal antibodies and polyclonal sera against the HIV-1 virus. 37 The design of an effective vaccine against HIV-1 has met with limited success so far, because 38 of the inability of immunogens to elicit broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) targeted to the 39 trimeric envelope (Env) glycoprotein, the sole viral antigen on the surface of the virus. Most 40 bNAbs isolated from infected individuals are directed to one of the major sites of vulnerability 41 on Env: V1/V2 loop apex, V3 loop, CD4-binding site, centre of the gp120 silent face, gp120-42 gp41 subunit interface, gp41 fusion peptide and membrane proximal external region (MPER) 43 of gp41. 44 We developed a facile methodology for mapping neutralizing HIV-1 epitopes at single residue 45 resolution. To this end, a library of single-site Cys mutations were engineered at selected 46 solvent-exposed sites in the Env glycoprotein on the surface of the virus. Cys mutants were 47 covalently labeled using a Cys reactive reagent (Maleimide-PEG2-Biotin) that masks epitope 48 residues, followed by infection of the labeled mutant viruses in mammalian cells in the 49 presence of bNAbs. Subsequently, deep sequencing of the env gene from bNAb-resistant 50 viruses was used to delineate epitopes ( Figure 1 ). We focused our epitope mapping efforts to 51 the Env ectodomain of the clade B, CCR5-tropic primary HIV-1 isolate JRFL, which has been 52 extensively characterized both biochemically and structurally, and is used as a model primary 53 virus.

A total of 81 solvent-exposed residues (Table S1) were selected from the X-ray crystal structure 55 of the pre-fusion HIV-1 Env ectodomain using a combined criterion of >30% solvent 56 accessibility and sidechain-sidechain centroid distance >8 Å ( Figure S1 ). This led to the 57 identification of a set of solvent-exposed residues which collectively exhibit uniform surface 58 coverage of the Env trimer ( Figure S2 ). These Env residues were mutated to Cys in the pLAI-59 JRFL molecular clone, pooled in equimolar quantities to create a plasmid DNA library, and 60 transfected in HEK293T cells to produce the Exposed Cys Library, a library of single-site Cys 61 mutant viruses. Wt Env lacks free Cys residues. In single-cycle and multi-cycle infectivity 62 assays, the Exposed Cys Library retained significant viral infectivity ( Figure S3 ) and was 63 therefore used for epitope mapping studies. Figure S4B ). Next, we covalently labeled the WT virus with 71 Maleimide-PEG2-Biotin, and measured single-cycle viral infectivity in TZM-bl cells. Since the 72 use of 10 mM label likely led to a high extent of label incorporation without adversely affecting 73 viral infectivity ( Figure S5 ), we used this concentration to label the WT virus and the Exposed 74 Cys Library.

To validate our methodology, proof-of-concept studies were carried out with the Exposed Cys 76 Library to map epitopes of bNAbs directed to distinct sites on Env. To decide the amount of 77 antibody to use, neutralization assays of WT LAI-JRFL virus were performed in TZM-bl cells, 78 in the presence of: CD4-binding site bNAb VRC01, V3-glycan targeting bNAb PGT128 and 79 gp120-gp41 interface specific bNAb PGT151. For epitope mapping studies, we used antibody 80 concentrations 100 times in excess of the calculated IC50 (Table S2) .

Mapping epitopes using the Exposed Cys Library necessitated env gene sequencing from 82 bNAb-resistant virion pools (Figure 1 ). Isolation of env clones was accomplished using HUT-83 R5, a T-cell line permissive to multi-cycle infection. To map known bNAb epitopes using our 84 methodology, we carried out multi-cycle infectivity assays of the labeled Exposed Cys Library 85 in the presence of 100 IC50 equivalents (and subsequent threefold dilutions) of bNAbs VRC01, 86 PGT128 and PGT151. Multi-cycle infectivity of the labeled Exposed Cys Library was found 87 to be similar in the absence and presence of the bNAb VRC01 ( Figure S6 ).

Since epitopes for the selected bNAbs are present in the Exposed Cys Library, some mutant 89 viruses are expected to be resistant to neutralization upon bNAb exposure. This was inferred 90 by quantifying the ratio of extracellular p24 levels for the labeled Exposed Cys Library in the 91 absence to presence of VRC01 and other bNAbs. The ratio of p24 levels was found to be ~1 92 for the labeled virus in the absence to presence of bNAbs ( Figure 2 ). This indicated that mutant 93 viruses became resistant to neutralization and proved that epitopes for these bNAbs are present 94 in the Exposed Cys Library, and can be mapped.

Delineating anti-HIV polyclonal antibody specificities using standard epitope mapping 96 techniques is challenging since the polyclonal antibody repertoire is most often comprised of 97 bNAbs that target multiple epitopes on Env. We therefore extended our methodology to 98 characterize epitope specificities of polyclonal sera elicited by HIV-1 infected individuals and 99 immunized animals. Plasma from a subtype-C HIV-infected elite neutralizer (NAB059) was 100 used for epitope mapping studies using our approach 4, 5 . Epitope mapping was also carried out 101 using sera from guinea pigs immunized with trimeric cyclic permutants of gp120 6 which were 102 previously shown to exhibit Tier 2 neutralization against a global panel of HIV-1 isolates 7 .

Multi-cycle infectivity assays of the labeled Exposed Cys Library were carried out in HUT-R5 104 cells, with 100 ID50 equivalents of NAB059 plasma or 10 ID50 equivalents of trimeric cyclic 105 permutant-immunized guinea pig sera. Both the NAB059 plasma and guinea pig sera were 106 found to select for neutralization resistant viruses in the labeled Exposed Cys Library ( Figure   107 S7), indicating that epitopes for these polyclonal antibodies are present in the library.

Deep sequencing of the env gene recovered from labeled virion pools in the presence and 109 absence of antibody/plasma/sera was subsequently carried out to map epitopes at single residue 110 resolution. The env gene was sequenced in 6 fragments with PCR primers containing unique 111 MID tags representing a particular selection condition: bNAb, plasma/sera or controls (Table   112 S3). A total of 69 Cys mutants were identified from the deep sequencing data. Of the 12 missing Table S4 ). Polyclonal NAB059 plasma contained quaternary epitope-124 specific and CD4-binding site-specific signatures (Table S4 ). The cyclic permutant immunized 125 sera contained epitope specificities mapping to the V1V2 loop and CD4-binding site (Table   126 S4), consistent with earlier observations using mammalian cell surface display and mutant 127 pseudoviruses 8, 9 . Both polyclonal sera were observed to encompass multiple antibody 128 specificities, which account for their observed neutralization activity.

Finally, we validated our epitope mapping strategy on a panel of epitope mutants of the bNAbs 130 from our deep sequencing data (Table S5) . Individual viruses containing a Cys mutation either 131 at or outside a bNAb epitope in Env were labeled with the Cys label, and viral infectivity assays 132 were performed in TZM-bl cells in the presence and absence of bNAbs. Titration of the viral 133 supernatant was carried out using both qRT-PCR ( Figure S8 , Table S6 ) as well as TZM-bl cell-134 based reporter assays ( Figure S9 ). We use site-directed Cys scanning mutagenesis, a powerful tool to probe protein function 14-17 .
Cys is an attractive candidate for mutagenesis since Cys at solvent-exposed sites in proteins 152 can be labeled site-specifically. In addition, Cys is relatively infrequent in the proteome, and
All bNAbs were obtained either from the NIH AIDS reagent program 186 (https://www.aidsreagent.org/) or the IAVI Neutralizing Antibody Consortium.

Residue selection for Exposed Cys Library. 188 A combined criterion of >30% solvent accessibility and sidechain-sidechain centroid distance 189 >8 Å was used to select 81 residues from the X-ray crystal structure of the pre-fusion HIV-1 Cys library generation. 204 To generate the Cys library, 81 selected exposed residues listed in Table S1 were individually Multiple cycle infectivity assay of Exposed Cys Library in HUT-R5 cells. 316 We carried out multi-cycle infectivity assays of the Exposed Cys Library in HUT-R5 cells (a Multi-cycle infectivity of labeled Exposed Cys Library in the presence of bNAbs. 334 To map epitopes of known bNAbs using our methodology, we carried out multi-cycle 335 infectivity assays of the labeled Exposed Cys Library in the presence of 100 IC50 equivalents 336 (and subsequent threefold dilutions) of bNAbs VRC01, PGT128 and PGT151. This was carried 337 out by labeling the Exposed Cys Library, followed by incubation with bNAbs for 1 hour at 338 37°C, prior to carrying out multi-cycle infectivity assays in HUT-R5 cells. Neutralization titre (ID50) determination of human plasma and guinea pig sera. 346 The neutralization titre or 50% inhibitory dose (ID50) was determined using the TZM-bl cell-347 based viral neutralization assay. Neutralization assays was carried out for the WT LAI-JRFL 348 virus in the presence of plasma from the elite neutralizer, NAB059 and also for terminal bleed 349 sera (collected at week 34.5) from guinea pigs immunized with cyclically permuted gp120 350 trimers. Similar to IC50, neutralization titre, or 50% inhibitory dose (ID50) is calculated as the 351 reciprocal of the serum dilution at which the RLUs in test wells (with plasma/sera) are reduced 352 by 50% in comparison to RLUs in virus control wells (without plasma/sera) after subtraction 353 of background RLUs from cell control wells. Titres 100 times in excess of the calculated ID50 354 were used to map epitopes of NAB059 plasma using the Exposed Cys Library. For mapping 355 epitopes using the immunized guinea pig sera, 10 times the ID50 titre was used, since only 356 limited amounts of these sera were available.

Multi-cycle infectivity assays of labeled Exposed Cys Library in the presence of 358 plasma/sera. 359 To map epitopes present in polyclonal sera (Figure 1) , multi-cycle infectivity assays in HUT-360 R5 cells 33 were carried out for the labeled Exposed Cys Library in the presence of 100 ID50 361 equivalents of NAB059 plasma or 10 ID50 equivalents of immunized guinea pig sera. Multi-362 cycle infectivity assays in the presence of plasma/sera were performed as described above for 363 bNAbs. Importantly, during the 1:2 cell split on every alternate day post infection of the labeled 364 library, additional plasma/sera was introduced into the culture media to keep the final titers 365 constant. From the multi-cycle infectivity data, the ratio of p24 levels of the labeled Exposed 366 Cys Library in the absence to presence of bNAb was also quantified. Finally, these reads were classified based on whether they were wildtype, or contained indels were also carried out to confirm that the observed amplification was specific.
The standard curve was used for the absolute quantification of viral cDNA. For this, viral RNA 457 was isolated from 500 μl of tissue culture supernatant harvested from HEK293T cells using a

Step 1: A library of single Cys mutants was created using site-directed mutagenesis at selected, 589 solvent exposed sites in the env gene of the HIV-1 molecular clone, pLAI-JRFL. The Env 590 ectodomain in this molecular clone is from the JRFL strain (residues 25 -690), whereas the 591 rest of the sequence is derived from the LAI strain of HIV-1. An equimolar pool of single-site 592 Cys mutants of env gene (cloned in pLAI-JRFL) was used to transfect HEK293T cells. This 593 led to the production of a library of mutant viruses, having Cys mutations at the selected solvent 594 exposed residues in the Env ectodomain; henceforth referred to as the Exposed Cys Library.
Step 2: The pool of mutant viruses was covalently labeled with a Cys reactive reagent (CRR),
EZ-Link™ Maleimide-PEG2-Biotin (Thermo Fisher Scientific), and infectivity was monitored 597 before and after labeling.
Step 3: At epitope residues, masking by the bulky Cys label prevents

The ratio of p24 levels was estimated from multi-cycle infectivity assays in the presence of 604 bNAbs VRC01, PGT128 and PGT151. After ~10 days of infection, the ratio of p24 levels of 605 the labeled viral library in the absence to presence of bNAbs is ~1 (red bar), confirming that 606 labelling at exposed, epitope residues on Env prevents neutralization by the corresponding 607 bNAb. In contrast, in the absence of labelling, viral entry is abolished in the presence of the 608 bNAb (black bar), leading to a high value of the ratio.

FIGREF1.text: Viral supernatants from HEK293T cells contain 20% Fetal Bovine Serum (FBS) which has a 65 high protein content (~30-40 mg/ml) and includes a large number of sulfhydryl groups that can 66 be labeled. This potentially necessitated the use of high concentrations of the Cys label for our 67 experiments. We exploited the high affinity interaction of the bacterial toxin CcdB and DNA 68 Gyrase 3 to quantify the extent of Cys labeling in the presence of 20% FBS, to mimic viral 69 labeling (Figure S4A). The use of 10 mM Cys label and overnight incubation led to the 70 maximum extent of labeling (

FIGREF2.text: 113 mutants, 10 mutants (D78C, R151C, N160C, N187C, E267C, E293C, D340C, N392C, N398C, 114 R440C) were not present in the plasmid DNA pool (no reads for MID 8) used for transfection, 115 and were likely lost while pooling. A couple of mutants (N88C and Q442C) were present in 116 the plasmid DNA pool (MID 8), but showed complete loss of infectivity upon Cys labeling (no 117 reads for MID 6). The number of reads for each Cys mutant in the presence of the 118 antibody/plasma/sera was normalized with respect to the corresponding number in the absence 119 as described in the Methods section. For virtually all mutants outside the epitope(s), this 120 normalized read ratio (R) is close to zero because antibody mediated neutralization eliminates 121 these mutants. Residues with R > 0.5 were designated as epitope residues. Epitopes of bNAbs 122 identified using our methodology were in excellent agreement with available structural 123 information (Figure 3,

FIGREF3.text: Viral infectivity assays of Cys mutant viruses were carried out in the presence of 100 IC50 136 equivalents (and threefold dilutions) of bNAbs VRC01, b12, PGT128 and PGT151. Viruses 137 became resistant to neutralization only when the corresponding epitopes were masked by the 138 bulky Cys label (Figure S10). Control experiments were carried out by labeling the epitope-139 Cys mutant virus in the presence of bNAbs targeting other sites on Env (Figure S11). The 140results clearly demonstrate that the methodology was able to distinguish between epitope and 141 non-epitope residues for each bNAb.

FIGREF4.text: High-throughput, site-directed scanning mutagenesis techniques are widely used in protein 143 engineering, which enable studies of protein structure and function at single residue resolution 1, 144 2, 10, 11 . A deep mutational scanning-based approach, "mutational antigenic profiling" was 145 recently used to map epitopes of nine HIV-1 bNAbs 12 . This approach is based on the creation146 of codon-mutant libraries 13 , identification of bNAb escape mutants and deep sequencing of 147 virus pools to quantify the enrichment of mutations after antibody selection. This method 148 comprehensively delineates regions of viral escape or functional epitopes, not all of which are 149 in physical contact with the antibody 12 .

FIGREF6.text: 153 introduction of Cys in proteins is most often accompanied by very little structural and 154 functional perturbation 18-20 . Moreover, our method is devoid of the complexity of saturation 155 mutagenesis libraries, which makes library construction and analysis of deep sequencing data 156 considerably simpler. Our library sizes are at least 20-60 times smaller than saturation 157 mutagenesis libraries. Our method appears to exclusively identify structurally defined epitope 158 residues that are in close physical proximity to the antibody (Figure 3). In contrast to recently 159 developed cryo-EM based epitope-mapping approaches 21 , the method does not require 160 sophisticated instrumentation, is highly parallelizable and can map epitopes to single residue 161 resolution. 162 These features make it an attractive approach to map neutralization responses in human sera 163 from either HIV-1 infected individuals or vaccinees. Knowledge of the three-dimensional 164 structure of the antigen is not a prerequisite for selecting residues for mutagenesis using the 165 proposed methodology. In the absence of structural information, homology modeling or Asp 166 scanning mutagenesis 22 can be employed to locate solvent accessible residues in proteins. 167 There is an urgent need for reliable epitope mapping techniques to elucidate neutralizing 168 epitopes against HIV-1 and others viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Deep sequencing of the 169 env gene recovered from labeled virion pools in the presence of a bNAbs/sera, using our 170 methodology provides comprehensive knowledge of epitope specificities, which in turn 171 provides useful insights about the nature of antibody response elicited by the virus 23-25 and 172 informs immunogen design 26, 27 . The methodology can readily be coupled to cell surface 173display methodologies 2 to obtain all, rather than just neutralization epitopes.

FIGREF7.text: directed Cys scanning mutagenesis was carried out in the env gene (~2.2 kb) of HIV-1 180 molecular clone pLAI-JRFL (11.7 kb), where LAI-JRFL refers to the strain of HIV-1. Since 181 site-directed mutagenesis is less efficient for larger plasmids (> 3.1 kb), the env gene was 182 subcloned in a smaller TA cloning vector pTZ57/R using the insTA clone PCR cloning kit 183 (Thermo Fisher Scientific).

FIGREF9.text: Env ectodomain (PDB ID: 4TVP). The solvent accessibility of each residue was calculated 191 using the NACCESS V 2.1.1 program (http://wolf.bms.umist.ac.uk/naccess/) after removing 192 antibody chains. Pairwise centroid distances between side chain centroids were calculated for 193 all residues exhibiting solvent accessibility >30% using an in-house PERL script. This 194 sidechain-sidechain centroid distance cut-off was chosen to leave out residues in contact 3 . The 195 81 selected residues occupy a surface area roughly corresponding to one-third of the total 196 surface area of the Env ectodomain (PDBePISA, EMBL-EBI). In addition, 47 out of the 83 197 selected exposed residues are contact residues either for CD4, the primary cellular receptor for198 HIV, or the following bNAbs directed to various neutralizing epitopes on the Env: CD4-199 binding site (VRC01, PGV04, 3BNC117, NIH45-46, CH103, b12), CD4-induced epitope 200 (17b), V3 glycan (PGT121-123, 125-128, 130, 131, 135), V1V2 glycan (PG9, CAP256-

FIGREF11.text: 205 mutated to Cys by site-directed mutagenesis using partially overlapping complementary 206 primers which generate a doubly-nicked amplicon 28 . There was a 21 bp overlap between the 207 forward and reverse partially overlapping primers, and a Cys codon was located 9 bp from the 208 5'-end of each primer. All primers were synthesized at the Protein and Nucleic Acid (PAN) 209 facility at Stanford University, USA.

FIGREF12.text: Site-directed mutagenesis reactions were carried out using Phusion DNA polymerase (NEB)211 according to the manufacturer's protocol in a thermal cycler PTC 200 (Bio-Rad). Each 20 µl 212 reaction had 20-25 ng of template (pTZ57/R-env), 1 µM of the primer pair, 1X GC Buffer, 200 213 µM dNTPs and 3% DMSO as an additive. PCR was done for 30 cycles with an annealing 214 temperature of 65°C for 35 seconds. The reaction mixture was subjected to DpnI digestion by 215 adding 0.5 µl DpnI (20 U/µl), 1 µl NEB Buffer 4 and 8.5 µl of the PCR product, followed by 216 incubation at 37°C for 6 hours. PCR products were purified using the GeneJET PCR 217 Purification kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Final elution of DNA was done in 20 µl MilliQ 218 water. An aliquot of 1 µl of the purified PCR product was used to transform E.coli TOP10 219 electrocompetent cells and following recovery, inoculated on Luria-Bertani plates containing 220 100 µg/ml Ampicillin. Plasmid was isolated from using commercially available mini-prep 221 columns (Qiagen). Incorporation of the Cys mutation at the selected positions in env was 222 confirmed by Sanger sequencing, carried out at Macrogen, South Korea.

FIGREF13.text: Single-Cys mutant pTZ57/R-env plasmids were pooled in equimolar quantities to create a 224 pooled plasmid DNA library. The env gene harbouring Cys mutations was amplified from 225 pTZ57/R-env plasmid pools using Phusion DNA Polymerase (NEB) and primers from the 5'226    and 3' ends of the gene to amplify the entire env, and subsequently cloned into the pLAI-JRFL 227 molecular clone between BamHI and SfiI restriction sites using T4 DNA ligase (NEB). This 228 was accomplished by replacement of the WT env gene from the pLAI-JRFL molecular clone 229 by digestion with BamHI and SfiI restriction enzymes, and subsequent purification of the 230 vector backbone fragment by electroelution at 100 volts in 0.5X TAE for 1 hour 30 minutes.231Following electroelution, the DNA fragment was extracted using phenol-chloroform-isoamyl232 alcohol (25:24:1), precipitated using Pellet Paint Co-Precipitant (EMD Millipore), and 233 subsequently, ligation and electrotransformation in E.coli TOP10 were carried out. The mutant 234 plasmid DNA library was purified using commercially available mini-prep columns (Qiagen) 235 using growth conditions of 30°C and 130 rpm to support the propagation of large plasmids. 236 Transient production of Cys mutant viruses. 237 The Exposed Cys viral Library was produced by transient transfection of the pLAI-JRFL 238 mutant plasmid DNA library into HEK293T cells. 24 hours before transfection, 5x10 5 cells 239 were seeded in each well of a 6-well plate, containing 2 ml of DMEM with 10% Fetal Bovine 240 Serum (FBS). The transfection mix contained 16 µg of transfection reagent, polyethyleneimine 241 (PEI) (Sigma-Aldrich) and 4 µg of mutant pLAI-JRFL plasmid (4:1 ratio of PEI:DNA), in a 242 final volume of 100 µl of serum-free DMEM. After 10 minutes of incubation at room 243 temperature, 100 µl of 10% DMEM was added to the transfection mix, and this was used to 244 transfect each well of a 6-well plate containing HEK293T cells at 50-70% confluency. Media 245 was replaced 6-8 hours post-transfection with 1.5-1.8 ml of 10% DMEM, and tissue culture 246 media was collected 48 hours post-transfection to harvest the virus. Culture media was 247 centrifuged at 1500 rpm for 10 minutes to remove residual cells. To the supernatant containing 248 viruses, FBS was added to a final concentration of 20%. Viral supernatants were aliquoted and 249 stored at -70°C. Titration of the viral supernatant was carried out using TZM-bl cell-based 250 reporter assays to determine viral infectivity. All studies with replication competent viruses 251 were carried out at the Biosafety Level-3 facility at the Centre for Infectious Disease Research 252 (CIDR) at IISc. 253 Single-cycle viral infectivity assay in TZM-bl cells. 254 Single-cycle infectivity assays of viral libraries harvested from HEK293T culture supernatants 255 were carried out using a luciferase reporter gene-based assay in TZM-bl cells. TZM-bl 256 (previously known as JC53BL-13) is a CXCR4-positive HeLa cell derivative, engineered to 257 constitutively express the primary cellular receptor of HIV, CD4 and the CCR5 co-receptor. 258 These cells are therefore permissive to infection by most HIV strains. Integrated into these cells 259 is a firefly luciferase reporter gene under the control of an HIV-1 LTR promoter. Upon viral 260 infection, the viral Tat protein activates the LTR promoter, and consequently, the extent of 261 infection can be directly quantified by luminescence measurements from TZM-bl cells. For the 262 assay, 100μl of undiluted and subsequent threefold-dilutions (in 10% DMEM) of viral 263 supernatant was added in successive wells of a 96-well tissue culture plate. To this, 1x10 4 264 freshly-trypsinized TZM-bl cells in 100 μl of 10% DMEM containing 30 μg/ml of DEAE-265 dextran was added and incubated for 48 hours. Subsequently, a 100 μl volume was discarded 266 from each well and 80μl of reconstituted Britelite Plus reagent (PerkinElmer) was added and 267 incubated for 2 minutes at room temperature. The reagent carries out cell lysis as well as the 268 luciferase enzymatic reaction. Following incubation, 130 μl was aspirated from each well and 269 transferred to a 96-well black plate and luminescence readings were measured using a VICTOR 270 X2 luminometer (PerkinElmer).

FIGREF14.text: Quantification of the extent of Cys labeling using MALDI-TOF.272    WT CcdB and the test protein, GyrA14-I491C were purified using previously standardized 273 protocols 29 . GyrA14-I491C was dissolved at 50 µM in 1X PBS buffer containing 20% FBS (to towards free sulfhydryl groups as opposed to primary amines in the protein 30 .

FIGREF15.text: Labeling was carried out for different concentrations of the label, i.e. 0.01 mM, 0.1 mM, 1 mM 279 and 10 mM and different time-points of incubation i.e., 15 mins, 1 hour, 4 hours and overnight; 280 in a final labeling volume of 100 µl at 4°C. Higher concentrations of the label exceeded the 281 maximum solubility and hence could not be used. Following labeling, the excess label was 282 removed using a PD Minitrap G-25 desalting column (GE Healthcare). The labeled GyrA14-283 I491C was loaded onto a pre-equilibrated CcdB affinity column prepared using Affi-gel 10 284 (Bio-Rad) as per the manufacturer's instructions, and incubated at 4°C for 4 hours on a rotary 285 mixer to enable binding. Unbound protein (containing FBS components) was removed by 286 washing the column with 10 times the bed volume of coupling buffer (0.05 M sodium 287 bicarbonate, 0.5 M NaCl, pH 8.3), and elution was done using 0.2 M Glycine, pH 2.5 into a 288 vial containing an equal volume of 400 mM HEPES, pH 8.5. Mass spectra of the elutes were 289 acquired on an UltrafleXtreme MALDI TOF (Bruker Daltonics). Mass of unlabeled test protein 290 was 17.5 kDa, and upon labeling, an increase in mass of ~0.5 kDa was seen, corresponding to 291 the mass of the Cys label. The approximate extent of Cys labeling of the GyrA14-I491C test 292 protein was calculated as: of the pLAI-JRFL plasmid into HEK293T cells leads to production of 295 replication competent WT LAI-JRFL virus. Prior to labeling, all virus stocks were made cell-296 free by filtration through a 0.45 µm syringe filter. 3x10 5 RLU equivalents (as determined by 297 TZM-bl titrations) of WT virus was labeled with 1mM and 10 mM EZ-Link™ Maleimide-298 PEG2-Biotin (Thermo Fisher Scientific) in 1X PBS, overnight, in a reaction volume of 100 µl 299 at 4°C. The effect of labeling on viral infectivity was measured in TZM-bl cells. 300 Neutralization potency (IC50) of WT virus with bNAbs. 301 The neutralization potency (IC50) of the WT LAI-JRFL virus with bNAbs VRC01, b12, 302 PGT128 and PGT151 was estimated using a viral neutralization assay in TZM-bl cells. This 303 assay measures the antibody-mediated neutralization of HIV-1, by quantifying the reduction in 304 relative luminescence units (RLUs) i.e. Tat-driven luciferase gene expression upon viral 305 infection. For this assay, 1-1.5x10 5 RLU equivalents of WT LAI-JRFL virus were incubated 306 with serial threefold dilutions of bNAbs for 1 hour at 37°C in a total volume of 100 µl of 10% 307 DMEM. To this, 1x10 4 freshly-trypsinized TZM-bl cells in 100μl containing 30μg/ml of 308 DEAE-dextran were added, and incubated for 48 hours. Luminescence measurements were 309 taken using the Britelite Plus reagent (PerkinElmer) on a VICTOR X2 luminometer 310 (PerkinElmer). Neutralization potency (IC50) is calculated as the sample dilution at which the 311 RLUs in test wells (with bNAb) are reduced by 50% in comparison to RLUs in virus control 312 wells (without bNAb) after subtraction of background RLUs from cell control wells. We used 313 concentrations 100 times in excess of the calculated IC50 with different bNAbs 31, 32 for 314 subsequent experiments.

FIGREF17.text: 317derivative of the human T-cell line HUT-78, stably transduced with the CCR5 coreceptor).

FIGREF18.text: Multi-cycle infectivity assays evaluate both the infectivity as well as the rate and efficiency of 319 virus production in cell culture over a course of time (replication fitness). For this assay, 5x10 6 320 HUT-R5 cells were infected with 3x10 5 RLU equivalents (as estimated from TZM-bl titrations) 321 of the Exposed Cys Library using DEAE-dextran (at a final concentration of 30 µg/ml) in a 322 total volume of 250 µl of RPMI 1640 medium containing 10% FBS. Infection was carried out 323 by incubation in a 37°C CO2 incubator for 2 hours, with occasional shaking every half an hour.324Excess virus from the infected cells was removed by washing with 45 ml of ice-cold 1X PBS.325Infected cells were centrifuged at 1200 rpm for 5 mins, the supernatant was discarded, and the326 cell pellet was resuspended in 6 ml of 10% RPMI 1640, transferred to a T-25 flask and kept in 327 a CO2 incubator. Cells were split in a 1:2 ratio every alternate day post-infection, and virus 328 replication was quantitated by measuring the p24 antigen released in culture supernatants at 329 different time points post-infection using HIV-1 p24 SimpleStep ELISA kit® (Abcam). Serial 330 dilutions of the HIV-1 p24 protein (strain 92418, subtype B) provided with the kit was used to 331 plot a standard curve and replication fitness of the WT virus and Exposed Cys Library was 332 measured by estimating the p24 levels from the standard curve.

FIGREF20.text: Importantly, during the 1:2 split on every alternate day post-infection, additional bNAb was 340 introduced into the culture media to keep the final bNAb concentration constant. Since epitopes 341 for the selected bNAbs are present in the Exposed Cys Library, some mutant viruses are 342 expected to be resistant to neutralization upon bNAb exposure. This was inferred by 343 quantifying the ratio of p24 levels for the labeled Exposed Cys Library in the absence to 344 presence of bNAb.

FIGREF21.text: Sequencing of env gene for epitope mapping.368    Replicative virus isolated from HUT-R5 culture supernatants on day 13 (post infection) was 369 used to isolate RNA and prepare cDNA using RT-PCR. To this end, viral RNA was isolated 370 from 500 μl of tissue culture supernatant harvested from HUT-R5 cells using a QIAamp® viral 371 RNA Mini Kit (Qiagen). Elution was carried out using RNase-free 0.1% diethyl pyrocarbonate 372 (DEPC)-treated water, instead of elution buffer AVE provided with the kit, since the latter 373 contains 0.04% sodium-azide which affects A220 and A280 readings. RNA yield and purity were374 quantitated spectrophotometrically using NanoDrop TM 2000. SuperScript TM III reverse 375 transcriptase (Thermo Fisher Scientific) was used to produce cDNA from viral RNA using a 376 primer which binds 811 bp downstream of the env gene. The primer pLAI-JRFL-NefOR-rev 377 has the sequence 5'-AGGCAAGCTTTATTGAGGC-3'. First-strand cDNA synthesis was 378 carried out from the purified viral RNA in a 25 μl reaction containing 100 ng of viral RNA, 1 379 μl (200 units) of SuperScript TM III reverse transcriptase (Thermo Fisher Scientific), 5 μl of 5X 380 First-Strand Buffer (Thermo Fisher Scientific), 0.5 µM of gene-specific primer (pLAI-JRFL-381 NefOR-rev), 1 μl of dNTP mix (containing 10 mM of each dNTP) and 1μl RNasin ribonuclease 382 inhibitor (Promega). The cDNA synthesis reaction was carried out at 42°C for 50 mins, 383 followed by inactivation of reverse transcriptase by heating at 70°C for 15 mins.

FIGREF22.text: 384Subsequently, env was amplified using Phusion® High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase (NEB)using385    Phusion HF buffer and primers specific to the 5' and 3' ends of env, pLAI-JRFL-env-F ). PCR was done for 30 cycles with an annealing 388 temperature of 60°C for 35 seconds. Amplified env cDNA was purified using a GeneJET PCR 389 purification kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific). This step was necessary to remove the Phusion 390 DNA polymerase which would otherwise degrade any overhangs subsequently generated.This was further amplified for deep sequencing. The length of the env gene is ~2.2 kb, whereas 392 the maximum length of DNA that can be sequenced on the Illumina HiSeq 2500 platform is 393 500 bases in a paired end sequencing run (2x250 bp). Because of the size restriction imposed 394 by Illumina sequencing, the env gene was sequenced in six fragments.395The env gene was sequenced from the Exposed Cys Library isolated under different conditions 396 (listed inTable S3). Primers were designed for each of the conditions, with a unique Multiplex397 IDentifier (MID) tag for each condition. For the first 5 fragments (Figure S16) both the forward 398 and reverse flanking primers begin with NNN, followed by 6 bases of the unique sequence tag 399 for each MID and the 21 bases complementary to the gene. The sixth fragment contained the 400 same flanking forward primer, but the reverse primer was devoid of the MID sequence. Each 401 MID sequence corresponds to one of the following conditions: 3 broadly neutralizing 402 antibodies (bNAbs VRC01, PGT128, PGT151), 2 sera (NAB059 patient sera and trimeric 403 cyclic permutant (CycP) guinea pig sera) and 3 controls (conditions 6-8,

FIGREF23.text: and substitutions (single, double, triple and multiple mutants). Single Cys mutants were sorted 430 based on read numbers. Normalization was carried out as follows: for Residue i in Fragment x 431 at MID y, where x = 1 -6, and y = 1 -5 432 Numerator (N) = (# Cys reads (i) / (Total (#Cys reads) + WT reads)) for Fragment x at MID y 433 Denominator (D) = (# Cys reads (i) / Total (#Cys reads)+ WT reads)) for Fragment x at MID 434 6. Normalized Value (R) = N/D. All residues with R > 0.5 were designated as epitope residues.435Alternative methods of normalization, for example, using the read ratio of a given Cys mutant436    at MID x, where x = 1-5 to that at MID 6 yielded very similar conclusions.437 Titration of viral supernatant using qRT-PCR of the pol gene. 438 Viral titre (or viral load) was measured using quantitative real time-PCR (qRT-PCR) of the 439 conserved HIV-1 pol gene (201 bp) using SYBR Green detection chemistry. To this end, serial 440 dilutions of the plasmid pLAI-JRFL were prepared, ranging from 10 1 to 10 8 copies/µl. 441 Dilutions of the plasmid were prepared in nuclease-free water containing 0.1 µg/µl BSA. qRT-442 PCR reactions were performed in 20 µl reaction volumes containing 10 µl of 2X iQ™ SYBR® 443 Green Supermix (Bio-Rad), 0.5 µM each of pol gene-specific forward and reverse primers, 1µl 444 of the serially diluted plasmid DNA template and 2 µg of BSA. Volume was adjusted using 445 nuclease-free water. A no template control reaction was also setup which contained all the 446 reaction components except the template. Sequences of the primers used to amplify the pol 447 gene: pLAI-JRFL-pol-forward: 5'-AGGAGCAGAAACGTTCTATGTAGATGG-3' and 448 pLAI-JRFL-pol-reverse: 5'-GCATATTGTGAGTCTGTTACTATATTTACT-3'. The qRT-449 PCR assay was performed on an iQ5 RT-PCR detection system (Bio-Rad) using the following 450 cycling conditions: initial denaturation at 94°C for 5 mins, followed by 40 cycles of 451 denaturation at 94°C for 30 secs, primer annealing at 60°C for 35 secs, and primer extension 452 at 72°C for 30 secs. The threshold cycle (CT) values were obtained from the fluorescence data 453 during amplification and used to plot a standard curve for the different dilutions of pLAI-JRFL 454 plasmid DNA. Melting curve analysis and agarose gel electrophoresis of the qPCR products455

First-strand 460 cDNA synthesis was carried out from the purified viral RNA in a 25 μl reaction containing 100 461 ng of viral RNA, 1 μl (200 units) of SuperScript TM III reverse transcriptase (Thermo Fisher Strategy for rapid epitope mapping of bNAbs against HIV-1.

FIGREF25.text: bNAbs from binding and neutralizing the epitope mutant viruses. Steps 4 & 5: Deep sequencing 599 of the env gene from antibody/sera-resistant virion pools was used to identify epitope residues 600 at single residue resolution. Ratio of p24 levels for the labeled Exposed Cys Library in the absence to 602 presence of bNAbs.

FIGREF26.text: Epitope mapping of bNAbs and sera/plasma. (A) Change in accessible surface 610 area upon binding to selected bNAbs (B) Normalized read frequencies following deep 611 sequencing. 612 The solvent accessible surface area for residue sidechains was calculated using the NACCESS 613 V 2.1.1 program. The buried surface area is calculated by subtracting the accessible surface 614 area of Env residue sidechains in the presence of the bNAb from the area in the absence of the 615 bNAb (ΔASA). Surface areas buried in complexes of Env with bNAbs VRC01, PGT128 and 616 PGT151 (PDB IDs 3NGB (for VRC01), 5C7K (for PGT128) and 5FUU (for PGT151) 617 respectively) were calculated. Read numbers for selected Cys mutants for the different 618 selection conditions (MIDs 1-5, corresponding to bNAbs and polyclonal sera) were obtained 619 from the deep sequencing data and normalized by the reads in the unselected condition, in the 620 absence of bNAbs (MID 6), as described in the Methods section.

TABREF0.text: . The PCR applied on these reads for quality filtering. After the quality filtering, reads not having the correct MID/primer set for env data were eliminated along with the reads having mismatched MIDs. Each filtered read will thus have only the MID, forward/reverse primer along with the gene segment of interest. Reads in each fragment were segregated into different bins based on the MID. Before binning, reads with insertions/deletions, with incomplete primer/MIDs (due to quality filtering) and those having incorrect pairs of primers were removed. Binned reads were aligned with the wild type sequence of the env gene corresponding to each fragment using Water v6.4.0.0 program 35 . Aligned reads were reformatted for ease of further processing.

back_matter.text: Scientific), 5 μl of 5X First-Strand Buffer (Thermo Fisher Scientific), 0.5 µM of pol gene-463 specific primer (pLAI-JRFL-pol-reverse), 1 μl of dNTP mix (containing 10 mM of each dNTP) 464 and 1μl RNasin ribonuclease inhibitor (Promega). The cDNA synthesis reaction was carried 465 out at 42°C for 50 mins, followed by inactivation of reverse transcriptase by heating at 70°C 466 for 15 mins.

To estimate viral titres, 2μl of viral cDNA from the first-strand reaction was used for absolute 468 quantification using the standard curve. For this, qRT-PCR of the pol gene was carried out 469 using SYBR Green chemistry using the same reaction components and cycling conditions that 470 had been used earlier for plasmid DNA, except that viral cDNA was used as the template. The

CT value obtained from the qRT-PCR data was used to estimate viral copy numbers from the 472 standard curve. An important assumption of this method is that the reverse transcription step is 473 100% efficient. Although the qRT-PCR assay is capable of accurately measuring viral titres, it 474 does not accurately measure infectious titres, since this assay also accounts for defective 475 particles that harbour non-native forms of the Env and consequently, do not give rise to 476 productive infection.
